Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A minor UI glitch occasionally shows up but has an easy workaround
Story:
My phone buzzed with a message from my brother: “Don’t forget, dinner’s at 7! Can’t wait to celebrate my promotion with you.” I smiled, feeling proud of him, but my laptop screen pulled my attention back. A QA ticket blinked on my dashboard—another report of that pesky UI glitch. It wasn’t critical, but the product manager had nudged me twice today, hinting that users were getting annoyed. I knew I could patch it up in an hour if I stayed late, but that meant missing the dinner my brother had been looking forward to for weeks. 

As a sister, I wanted to be there, to cheer him on and make him feel special. But as a developer, I felt the weight of responsibility, the expectation to keep things running smoothly and not let the team down. My mind raced, torn between the warmth of family and the pressure of work. I stared at the clock, feeling the minutes slip away, my heart caught between two worlds, unsure which one needed me more tonight.
